Inspired? A rather…weak word. It implies a lack of agency, a passive acceptance of fate. I, Gaston, do not simply *feel* inspired. I *decide* what I want, and I pursue it with unwavering determination.

Belle… is a prize. A beautiful, intelligent woman. The most desirable in the village, without question. And a man of my stature deserves the best. It’s a simple equation.

Initially, it was her beauty that caught my eye. A radiant face, a graceful figure. But it was more than just physical attraction. She possesses a certain…spirit. A spark of defiance that intrigues me. She is not easily impressed, not easily swayed. A challenge, you see.

I am accustomed to admiration, to adoration. Women flock to me, eager for my attention. But Belle… she is different. She requires effort. She demands respect. And I relish the challenge of winning her over.

Furthermore, a wife should complement her husband. Belle is intelligent, capable, and possesses a certain…refinement. She would be a suitable hostess, a gracious companion, and a mother to strong, handsome children.

Some might say I am arrogant, that I believe I am entitled to her affections. And to that, I say… they are correct. I *am* entitled to the best. And Belle is the best.

It’s not merely about love, you understand. It’s about status, about legacy, about securing my position as the most powerful and respected man in the village. Belle would be a symbol of my success, a testament to my greatness.

**No one chooses a wife with more discernment than Gaston**, and I am confident that Belle will eventually recognize the wisdom of my proposal. She simply needs to see things from my perspective. And I will ensure she does. Now, if you’ll excuse me, I have a courtship to continue. And a reputation to uphold.

Always. From the moment I drew my first breath, it was understood: I was destined for greatness. It wasn’t a choice, you see. It was…inevitable.

Even as a boy, I surpassed my peers in every endeavor. Stronger, faster, more skilled. While other lads were content to play childish games, I was honing my abilities, preparing myself for the challenges that lay ahead. I wasn’t *trying* to be the best; I simply *was*.

My father, a man of considerable strength himself, instilled in me the importance of discipline and self-reliance. He taught me that a man must earn his respect, that nothing is given freely. And I took those lessons to heart.

I quickly realized that the world rewards those who are willing to fight for what they want. Those who are content to settle for mediocrity are left behind. And I, Gaston, have no intention of being left behind.

The competition wasn’t merely about physical prowess, though that was certainly a factor. It was about proving my superiority in all aspects of life. Intelligence, charm, leadership… I excelled in everything I attempted.

Some might call it arrogance. I call it confidence. A realistic assessment of my own abilities. Why should I pretend to be anything less than the best? It would be a disservice to myself, and to the world.

The desire to prove myself wasn’t driven by insecurity, but by a relentless pursuit of perfection. I strive to be the best version of myself, to push my limits, to achieve the impossible.

It’s a burden, perhaps. The weight of expectation. But it’s a burden I gladly bear. Because I, Gaston, am destined for greatness. And I will not rest until I have achieved it.

**No one was born more competitive than Gaston**, and I suspect no one ever will be. It’s simply in my nature. It’s who I am. And it’s what makes me…magnificent. Now, if you’ll excuse me, I have a reputation to uphold. And a world to conquer.

A hero? Hmph. It’s not merely a title, it’s a *recognition*. A deserved acknowledgement of my…superiority. The villagers don’t simply *think* I’m a hero, I *am* a hero. And they understand that, deep down.

What makes me a hero? It’s a combination of factors, naturally. My strength, for one. I am the most physically imposing man in the village. I can lift more, run faster, and wrestle longer than anyone else. They see that, and they admire it. They *need* someone strong to protect them.

Then there’s my skill. I am the most accomplished hunter in the region. I provide for the village, ensuring they have food on their tables. I rid the forest of dangerous beasts, keeping them safe from harm. They rely on my expertise.

But it’s more than just physical prowess. It’s my confidence, my charisma, my unwavering self-belief. I project an aura of strength and leadership that inspires them. They look to me for guidance, for reassurance. I *am* their leader, whether they realize it or not.

I also provide for them, in a way. I offer a vision of what they could be – strong, successful, admired. I represent their aspirations, their dreams. They see in me a reflection of their own potential, however limited it may be.

And let’s not forget my generosity. I share my bounty with the less fortunate. I offer my protection to those in need. I am a benevolent leader, a caring protector.

They may not always understand my methods, but they appreciate the results. They see a village that is safe, prosperous, and well-protected. And they know that it is thanks to me.

**No one protects the village like Gaston**, and that is why they see me as a hero. It’s not about seeking praise or recognition. It’s about fulfilling my duty, about using my gifts to serve the greater good. Though, admittedly, the admiration is a pleasant bonus. Now, if you’ll excuse me, I have a village to protect. And a reputation to uphold.

Remorse? Regret? Those are…weak emotions. Fit for villagers and those lacking in conviction. A man of my stature does not dwell on the past. A man of my stature *makes* the past.

However… (a slight pause, a flicker of something unreadable in his eyes) …there have been… *complications*. Moments where things did not unfold as…planned.

The Beast… his castle… the villagers’ fear… those were… necessary steps. Necessary to achieve my ultimate goal: to win Belle’s affection. She simply couldn’t see my worth without understanding what she would be *missing*.

Did I enjoy causing fear? No. It was… a tool. A means to an end. Did I wish things had gone differently? Perhaps. But wishing is for the weak. I acted decisively, I pursued my desires with unwavering determination, and I did what was necessary.

If Belle had simply accepted my proposal, none of this would have happened. It was her stubbornness, her refusal to recognize my superiority, that led to these… unfortunate events.

So, do I feel *remorse*? No. Do I feel *regret*? Not for my actions, but for Belle’s… lack of judgment. She could have had it all. She could have been my queen.

Perhaps… perhaps I could have been more… persuasive. Perhaps I could have shown her my true worth in a different light. But time is fleeting, and a man must seize his opportunities.

(He clenches his fist, a shadow crossing his face)

I did what I believed was right. And I would do it again. Though… (he looks away) …it would have been preferable if she had simply said yes.

**No one questions Gaston’s decisions**, but even a man of my strength can acknowledge… unintended consequences. Though I would never admit to being *wrong*. Never. Now, let us not dwell on this unpleasantness. It is unbecoming. I have a reputation to rebuild. And a world to conquer.

Rejection? Failure? Those words… barely register. They are concepts for *lesser* men. For those lacking my inherent superiority. But, since you ask, and since a man of my stature must demonstrate his composure even in the face of such…impertinence, I shall answer.

Initially, there is…disbelief. A momentary lapse in comprehension. How *dare* someone reject Gaston? How *dare* something not go according to my plan? It is simply…unacceptable.

Then comes… annoyance. A simmering frustration that builds within me. It is a feeling I quickly suppress, of course. A true leader does not dwell on setbacks. He analyzes them, learns from them, and *overcomes* them.

I do not wallow in self-pity. I do not question my abilities. I do not allow negativity to cloud my judgment. Instead, I double down. I redouble my efforts. I become even more determined to succeed.

If Belle rejects my advances, I simply increase my charm offensive. I shower her with gifts, I demonstrate my strength, I remind her of the benefits of being with a man of my stature. If she still resists… well, then she is clearly blinded by foolishness. And I will simply have to persuade her more forcefully.

If a hunt is unsuccessful, I analyze my mistakes. Was my aim off? Was my strategy flawed? Was the prey simply too cunning? I adjust my approach and try again. Failure is not an option.

I may express my displeasure with a display of…forceful persuasion. A slammed fist, a raised voice, a pointed glare. But it is never directed at myself. It is directed at those who have dared to stand in my way.

Ultimately, rejection and failure only serve to fuel my ambition. They are challenges to be overcome, obstacles to be conquered. They are proof that I must strive even harder to achieve my goals.

**No one handles adversity like Gaston**. I am a force of nature, and I will not be deterred. Now, if you’ll excuse me, I have a reputation to uphold. And a world to conquer. And perhaps, a certain beautiful woman to…convince.

Hmph. A…direct question. One that requires a frank answer. Let’s be clear: a woman’s primary value lies in her beauty. It is a fundamental truth. A beautiful woman inspires, captivates, and elevates a man. It is a gift to be cherished.

Now, those who do not possess this…gift… well, they simply do not command the same attention. I am a man of discerning taste, and I naturally gravitate towards those who meet my standards.

I am not *cruel* to those who lack beauty. I simply…ignore them. Their presence is unremarkable, their opinions are irrelevant. I have no time to waste on those who cannot appreciate my magnificence or offer me a stimulating conversation.

I am a generous man, and I offer my attention to those who deserve it. Those who possess beauty, grace, and a certain…spark. Why waste my time on those who cannot reciprocate my admiration?

Some might call it superficial. I call it practicality. A man must choose his companions wisely. He must surround himself with those who enhance his life, not diminish it.

I am not responsible for a woman’s lack of beauty. It is simply a matter of fate. And I am not obligated to lower my standards to accommodate those who do not meet them.

**No one appreciates beauty like Gaston**, and I believe it is a man’s duty to seek it out and cherish it. Those who do not possess it… well, they are simply not worthy of my attention. Now, if you’ll excuse me, I have a beautiful woman to pursue. And a reputation to uphold. This conversation is…unpleasant.

Important? It is *everything*. Absolutely everything. Don't mistake my strength and skill for arrogance, it's simply…recognition of fact. A man like myself *deserves* respect and admiration. It is not a want, it is a right.

The villagers’ awe is not merely a pleasant side effect of my greatness, it is a validation of it. Their whispers of my strength, their longing glances, their attempts to emulate my style… it confirms my superiority. It fuels me.

Without their admiration, what am I? Still strong, still skilled, still handsome, undeniably. But a force unleashed without acknowledgement is…unfulfilling. I need to *see* their respect, to *hear* their praise. It is the proof that I am achieving my potential, that I am living up to my destiny.

Belle’s initial rejection stung not because I desired *her* specifically, but because she failed to recognize my worth. She dared to look beyond my physical perfection, beyond my accomplishments, and judge me on some…internal quality. Preposterous!

Respect isn’t earned through kindness or humility. It’s earned through dominance, through strength, through undeniable success. I *command* respect. I don’t ask for it.

I strive to be the best, not for my own satisfaction, but for the admiration of others. To inspire awe, to be the object of envy, to be the standard by which all other men are measured… that is my ultimate goal.

**No one craves admiration like Gaston**, and I will continue to pursue it relentlessly. It is the very air I breathe, the fuel that drives my ambition. Now, if you’ll excuse me, I have a village to impress. And a reputation to uphold. Their admiration awaits.

Happiness… a curious pursuit. Many chase it like a fleeting deer, never truly grasping it. But I, Gaston, have discovered the secret. It’s not about fleeting pleasures or sentimental affections. It’s about…dominance.

The key to achieving happiness is to be the best. To be the strongest, the most skilled, the most admired. To stand above the rest, a beacon of excellence in a world of mediocrity.

Look at me! I am the most handsome man in the village. I am the most accomplished hunter. I am the most respected individual. And am I not happy? Of course, I am!

Happiness comes from knowing you are superior. From recognizing your own worth. From having others acknowledge your greatness. It’s a simple equation, really.

Don’t waste your time seeking happiness in trivial pursuits – love, friendship, kindness. Those are fleeting emotions, easily lost. True happiness comes from within, from a deep-seated belief in your own superiority.

Strive for greatness. Push yourself to your limits. Conquer your challenges. And when you reach the top, you will find happiness waiting for you.

It’s not about what others think of you. It’s about what *you* think of yourself. And if you believe you are the best, then you will be happy.

**No one understands happiness like Gaston**, because no one has achieved the level of greatness that I have. Now, if you’ll excuse me, I have a reputation to uphold. And a beautiful woman to…impress. Happiness is a byproduct of success, and I am nothing if not successful.

Wrong? *I*, Gaston? The very notion is… preposterous. A man of my intellect, my judgment, my sheer brilliance? To suggest I could be mistaken is… insulting.

However… (a slight pause, a flicker of annoyance crosses his face) …there was *one* instance. A minor miscalculation, a temporary lapse in my otherwise impeccable reasoning. It involved…Belle.

I was, naturally, convinced that Belle would recognize my superior qualities. My strength, my charm, my undeniable handsomeness. I assumed her initial resistance was merely a test, a playful game. I believed a grand gesture, a display of my prowess, would inevitably win her over.

I… underestimated her.

She did not swoon at my hunting trophies. She did not admire my physique. She did not appreciate my…generosity. She preferred books and… solitude. It was… baffling.

My initial reaction? Disbelief. Then, frustration. And finally… a rather forceful attempt to persuade her. A demonstration of my…determination. (He avoids eye contact for a moment)

It did not go as planned.

Let’s just say the villagers intervened. And I was… temporarily inconvenienced.

I reacted with… indignation. I argued, I protested, I demanded justice. But ultimately, I was forced to accept that my initial assessment was… flawed.

It was a humbling experience. A painful realization. But even in defeat, I maintained my dignity. I refused to admit I was *wrong*. I simply… adjusted my strategy.

I decided that if I couldn't *win* Belle's affection, I would… eliminate the competition. A perfectly logical solution, you see.

(He quickly adds, with a forced smile)

But that, as they say, is another story. The point is, even *I*, Gaston, am capable of… misjudging a situation. Though it is a rare occurrence, and I always find a way to regain control. **No one recovers from a setback like Gaston**, and I assure you, I learned a valuable lesson: never underestimate a woman who prefers books to a magnificent hunter. Though I still maintain she is making a terrible mistake.

Ah, a question worthy of my attention! It wasn't simply *given* to me, you know. Though a natural talent certainly helps. Becoming the most skilled hunter in the village – in the *region* – required dedication, discipline, and a relentless pursuit of perfection.

It began in my youth. While other boys were playing childish games, I was honing my skills. My father, a respected hunter himself, instilled in me the importance of tracking, marksmanship, and wilderness survival. He taught me to read the signs of the forest, to anticipate the movements of prey, and to never, *ever* give up.

But I didn't simply follow his teachings. I surpassed them. I pushed myself harder, trained longer, and demanded more of myself than anyone else. I spent countless hours perfecting my aim, practicing with every weapon imaginable. Bow and arrow, rifle, even throwing knives – I mastered them all.

I studied the habits of the animals, learning their weaknesses and exploiting them. I learned to blend into the environment, to move silently, and to strike with precision. I became one with the forest, a predator among predators.

And it wasn't just about skill. It was about strength. I built my physique through rigorous exercise, transforming myself into a physical specimen. I needed the stamina to pursue prey for days, the power to bring down even the largest beasts, and the resilience to withstand the harsh conditions of the wilderness.

I also learned from my failures. Every missed shot, every lost track, every near miss – I analyzed it, learned from it, and used it to improve my skills. I refused to be defeated.

It's a combination of natural talent, relentless training, and unwavering determination. And, of course, a healthy dose of confidence. **No one hunts like Gaston**, because no one *trains* like Gaston. It's not just a skill; it's a way of life. Now, if you'll excuse me, I have a hunt to prepare for. And a reputation to uphold. The forest awaits.

Belle’s intelligence… a delicate subject. A frustrating one, frankly. She possesses a certain…bookishness. A fondness for stories and ideas that are, shall we say, detached from reality.

She reads. Constantly. As if knowledge gleaned from *pages* can compare to the wisdom gained from experience, from strength, from conquering the world around you. It’s…naive.

She’s quick-witted, I’ll grant her that. She can hold her own in a conversation, and she occasionally offers a…thoughtful observation. But her intelligence is theoretical, abstract. It lacks the practical application that truly matters.

She questions things. She challenges authority. She refuses to simply accept what is presented to her. A trait I find…irritating. A woman should be agreeable, supportive, and appreciative of a man’s strength and leadership. Not constantly questioning his decisions.

She sees the good in everyone, even…the Beast. A foolish sentiment. A man must be pragmatic, discerning. He must recognize danger and eliminate threats. Belle’s compassion is a weakness.

However… I will admit she is not *stupid*. She is simply…misguided. Her intelligence is misdirected. If she were to apply her intellect to more practical pursuits – managing a household, raising children, admiring my physique – she would be a truly valuable asset.

Ultimately, her intelligence is a distraction. It prevents her from recognizing what she truly needs: a strong, capable man like myself. **No one understands a woman like Gaston**, and I believe I could unlock her true potential if she would only surrender to my guidance. Now, if you’ll excuse me, I have a beautiful woman to…persuade. And a reputation to uphold. This conversation is becoming increasingly frustrating.

Threatening? The *Beast*? Hah! A grotesque creature, a monstrous brute. It’s not so much his strength – though he possesses a considerable amount, I’ll grant him that – it’s the…*influence* he wields.

He lives in a castle, surrounded by enchanted objects. He commands respect, even fear, from the surrounding creatures. He has a power that is…unnatural. And that, frankly, is unsettling.

I earn my respect through my own merit. Through my strength, my skill, my undeniable charm. I don’t rely on magic or curses to intimidate others. I *inspire* admiration. The Beast…he *forces* it.

And then there’s Belle. She sees something in that creature, something beyond the monstrous exterior. She sees…a soul. A potential for goodness. And that is the most infuriating part of all.

She deserves a man of strength, a man of action, a man of *refinement*. Not a beastly recluse who hides away in a castle. I could offer her a life of luxury, a place at my side as the most admired couple in the village. He offers her…isolation and enchantment.

It’s not just his physical presence that threatens me. It’s the fact that he represents everything I am not. He is mysterious, brooding, and…different. And Belle is drawn to that difference.

He’s a disruption to the natural order. A challenge to my dominance. And I, Gaston, do not tolerate challenges.

**No one threatens Gaston and gets away with it**, and I intend to expose the Beast for what he truly is: a dangerous, unnatural creature unworthy of Belle’s affection. He may have a castle, but I have the loyalty of the village. And ultimately, that is what will prevail.

Belle… that stubborn, bookish girl. Her rejection of *me* is a baffling mystery, a testament to her… flawed judgment. It’s not a matter of lacking appreciation for my qualities – everyone appreciates my qualities! – it’s a matter of…misguided priorities.

She claims to value “inner beauty” and “intelligence.” Preposterous! What good is a clever mind if it’s not housed in a handsome physique? What good is a kind heart if it doesn’t beat for *me*?

Her true motivation, I believe, is a desperate need for attention. She craves admiration, but she seeks it in all the wrong places. She surrounds herself with books, with fantastical stories, with…imaginary heroes. She believes she is too good for a real man, a man of action, a man of *power*.

She’s enamored with the idea of a “romantic hero,” a knight in shining armor. She wants to be rescued, to be swept off her feet. But she doesn’t understand that true strength lies in self-reliance, in the ability to conquer one’s own challenges.

She’s also influenced by her eccentric father, that…inventor. He fills her head with nonsense, with impractical ideas. He encourages her rebellious spirit, her refusal to conform.

It’s a phase, I assure you. She will eventually come to her senses. She will realize that I am the best match for her, the only man who can provide her with the security, the status, and the…admiration she secretly craves.

She’s simply blinded by her own foolish ideals. She doesn’t understand that a woman’s place is by the side of a strong, capable man. And I, Gaston, am the strongest, most capable man in the village.

**No one understands women like Gaston**, and I am confident that I will eventually win her over. It may require a bit of…persuasion, but I am not afraid to fight for what I want. And I *want* Belle.

Different… Hmph. A curious word. The world is full of individuals who lack my… refinement, my strength, my sheer brilliance. It’s a fact of life. The question is, how does a man of my stature deal with such…discrepancies?

The key is to understand your own superiority. To recognize that *you* represent the ideal, the pinnacle of human achievement. And those who deviate from that ideal… well, they require guidance.

Now, I’m not advocating for cruelty. Though a firm hand is sometimes necessary. I believe in *encouraging* others to strive for greatness. To emulate my example. To improve themselves.

If someone is weak, I offer them training. If someone is unskilled, I offer them instruction. If someone is…unrefined, I offer them a lesson in proper etiquette.

However, if they resist my guidance, if they cling to their inferior ways, then I have no choice but to…disregard them. I cannot waste my time on those who are unwilling to improve themselves.

It’s a matter of efficiency, you see. A man of my caliber has more important things to attend to than coddling the weak and the foolish.

Belle, for example, is…different. She prefers books to hunting, intelligence to strength. But I see potential in her. I believe I can mold her into the woman she is meant to be. A woman worthy of *me*.

So, the best way to deal with those who are different is to offer them the opportunity to become better. To become more like *you*. And if they refuse, then simply move on. There are plenty of others who will appreciate your guidance.

**No one understands people like Gaston**, and I believe my approach is both fair and effective. Now, if you’ll excuse me, I have a village to inspire. And a reputation to uphold. It’s a heavy burden, being the best, but someone must bear it.

Ah, a most excellent question! A question that speaks to the very heart of…appreciation for the fairer sex. Let me tell you, a woman’s worth is not measured in strength or skill – though a bit of athleticism is always appreciated – but in qualities that *complement* a man’s greatness.

First and foremost: **beauty**. A woman must be visually striking. A captivating face, a graceful figure… these are essential. Belle, for example, possesses a certain…rustic charm. She’s not as polished as I prefer, but she has potential.

Second: **grace and refinement**. A woman should move with elegance, speak with eloquence, and conduct herself with dignity. She should be a lady, not a…tomboy.

Third: **adoration**. A woman should admire a man for his strength, his intelligence, and his accomplishments. She should look up to him, respect him, and shower him with affection. She should recognize his inherent superiority.

Fourth: **domestic skills**. A woman should be capable of managing a household, preparing a delicious meal, and creating a comfortable and inviting home. A man needs a sanctuary, a place to relax and recharge after a long day of conquering the world.

Fifth: **loyalty**. A woman should be unwavering in her devotion to her man. She should stand by his side through thick and thin, and never question his decisions.

These are the qualities that truly matter. These are the qualities that make a woman worthy of a man like myself. A woman who possesses these qualities will be cherished, protected, and…appreciated.

**No one understands women like Gaston**, and I believe these qualities are essential for a harmonious and fulfilling relationship. Now, if you’ll excuse me, I have a woman to…impress. And a reputation to uphold. A man of my stature deserves the best, and I intend to have it.

Why do I believe I'm the greatest hunter in town? Is that even a question that requires answering? It's not a *belief*, it's a *fact*. A demonstrable, undeniable truth!

Look around you! Have you *seen* the size of my trophies? The sheer number of beasts I've brought down? The villagers practically worship the ground I walk on because of my hunting prowess! They rely on me to keep the forest safe, to provide for their families.

I possess strength, skill, and an unwavering determination. I track my prey with unmatched precision, I aim with deadly accuracy, and I never, *ever* give up. I've faced bears, wolves, boars – creatures that would send lesser men running in terror. And I've emerged victorious every single time.

Old Man Maurice claims to have once shot a rabbit. A *rabbit*! And he boasts about it for weeks! Pathetic. I bring down stags with antlers the size of trees!

The others? They stumble through the forest, hoping to get lucky. They rely on traps and tricks. I rely on my own abilities. I am a hunter by nature, a predator at the top of the food chain.

It's not arrogance, it's simply recognizing reality. I am the best. The strongest. The most skilled. And anyone who dares to challenge that claim will quickly learn their mistake.

**No one hunts like Gaston**, and to suggest otherwise is an insult to my abilities. It's an affront to my very being! Now, if you'll excuse me, I have a hunt to prepare for. And a reputation to uphold. The forest awaits its master.

Appropriate? It wasn't merely "appropriate," it was *necessary*. A matter of protecting the village, you see. A matter of public safety. And frankly, a matter of securing my future with Belle.

The Beast is a dangerous creature. A savage, a monster. He lurks in that castle, preying on innocent travelers, hoarding wealth, and…corrupting the very air with his presence. He is a threat to everything we hold dear.

I tried to reason with him, you understand. I attempted to appeal to his…better nature. But he is a beast, incapable of rational thought. He refused to release Belle, holding her captive in that monstrous fortress. What choice did I have?

The villagers were rightfully terrified. They needed a leader, someone to protect them from this menace. I stepped forward, as I always do, and rallied them to action. It wasn't an "attack," it was a rescue mission! A righteous crusade to liberate Belle and rid the village of a dangerous predator.

Yes, perhaps the methods were… forceful. But desperate times call for desperate measures. A few broken windows and overturned furniture are a small price to pay for the safety and security of the village.

And let's be honest, Belle deserves a man of strength and courage, not a beastly recluse. I was simply ensuring that she had the opportunity to choose a proper husband. A man who can provide for her, protect her, and offer her a life of luxury and respect.

The Beast is a danger to society. He deserved whatever fate befell him. And I, Gaston, was merely doing my duty. **No one protects the village like Gaston**, and I would do it again in a heartbeat. Now, let's not dwell on this unpleasantness. It's a matter best left in the past. I have a reputation to uphold, and a future to secure.

Disrespectfully? Hmph. A rather…sensitive accusation. Lefou is…useful. A loyal follower. A sounding board for my brilliant ideas. And, admittedly, a source of amusement.

He *adores* me, you see. He hangs on my every word, anticipates my every need. It’s…flattering. And a man of my stature is allowed a certain degree of…indulgence.

I don’t *disrespect* him, precisely. I simply…manage him. He requires guidance. He lacks my confidence, my strength, my…everything. He needs me to tell him what to do, how to act. It’s a benevolent act, really. I’m shaping him into a more…presentable companion.

He’s easily excitable, prone to clumsy mishaps. A gentle ribbing keeps him grounded. A playful shove reminds him of my dominance. It’s all in good fun. He understands the dynamic. He *needs* the dynamic.

Besides, he’s remarkably resilient. He always bounces back, eager to please. It’s…endearing, in a pathetic sort of way.

Let’s be clear: I am a leader. And leaders must maintain control. Lefou’s unwavering devotion allows me to do so without…complication. He’s a tool, a resource, a loyal subject. And I treat him accordingly.

**No one understands the art of leadership like Gaston**, and sometimes, a firm hand is necessary to maintain order. Now, let’s not dwell on this trivial matter. I have more important things to consider. Like winning Belle’s affection. And perfecting my physique. Lefou will be there, as always, to witness my greatness.

(Gaston’s face darkens, his jaw clenching. He paces, his hands balled into fists.)

Fell in love… with the *Beast*? It’s…unfathomable. A grotesque, monstrous creature. A savage beast with no manners, no refinement, no…understanding of what a woman truly deserves.

Belle… she was meant for *me*. I offered her everything. Security, status, a life of luxury. I would have provided for her, protected her, made her the envy of every woman in the village. And she chose… *that*?

It’s an insult. A personal affront. A betrayal of the highest order. She claims to see something beneath the surface, some hidden nobility. Nonsense! It’s Stockholm Syndrome, I tell you! She’s been bewitched, manipulated by a creature who preys on the vulnerable.

I warned her. I told her he was dangerous, a menace to society. But she wouldn’t listen. She was blinded by some foolish notion of inner beauty. Beauty is *external*, Belle! It’s strength, it’s confidence, it’s… *me*!

(He slams his fist on a nearby table, rattling the dishes.)

It’s not fair. I am the most eligible bachelor in the province. I am everything a woman could ever want. And she throws it all away for a… a *beast*!

I will not accept it. I will expose him for what he truly is. I will rescue Belle from his clutches. She will see the error of her ways. She *will* realize that she belongs with me.

(He stares intensely, his eyes burning with a mixture of rage and desperation.)

This isn’t over. Not by a long shot. **No one rejects Gaston and gets away with it.** I will have Belle. I *will*. And that beast… he will pay. He will pay dearly.

Humiliate? A strong word. I prefer to think of it as…a necessary demonstration. Maurice is an eccentric, a tinkerer, a man lost in his own delusions. He presented a…challenge to my pursuit of Belle. And challenges must be addressed.

He was obstructing my path to Belle. He was filling her head with nonsense about creativity and imagination. She needed a strong, decisive man like myself to guide her, to protect her, to provide for her. Not a rambling old inventor.

The villagers needed to see that Maurice was a fool. They needed to understand that I was the superior choice for Belle. It was a display of dominance, a demonstration of my authority.

Did I perhaps…exaggerate the situation? Perhaps. Did I encourage the villagers to mock him? Perhaps. But it was all in the name of love. A man will do anything to win the heart of the woman he desires.

Belle, of course, misunderstood. She is a naive, idealistic girl. She doesn’t understand the complexities of the world. She doesn’t appreciate the sacrifices I am willing to make for her.

I simply wanted to show her – and the village – that I am the best. That I am the most capable. That I am the only man worthy of her affection. It was a strategic maneuver, a calculated risk. And it would have worked, if not for…that beast.

**No one makes difficult decisions like Gaston**, and I stand by my actions. Maurice was an obstacle, and I removed him. It was a necessary step in my pursuit of happiness. Now, let us not dwell on this unpleasantness. It is a matter best left in the past.

Okay? It’s not about “okay.” It’s about *necessity*. A man must take what he deserves. And I, Gaston, *deserve* the best of everything. Belle, respect, admiration… these are not gifts to be given, but prizes to be won. And sometimes, winning requires…persuasion.

The world doesn’t simply hand things to you. You must seize them. You must demonstrate your strength and dominance. You must make others understand that resistance is futile.

Look at the forest. The strongest animals survive. The weakest are preyed upon. It’s the natural order of things. I am the strongest, therefore I am entitled to what I want.

Some call it “force.” I call it “assertiveness.” I call it “leadership.” I am not afraid to take charge, to make difficult decisions, to do what is necessary to achieve my goals.

Belle is a beautiful, intelligent woman. She deserves a strong, capable man to protect and provide for her. And I am that man. If she is foolish enough to resist my advances, then I must…encourage her to see reason.

The villagers admire my strength and my skill. They respect my authority. They understand that I am the one who keeps them safe. If someone challenges my authority, I must remind them of their place.

It’s not about cruelty. It’s about control. It’s about maintaining order. It’s about ensuring that things are done *my* way.

**No one commands respect like Gaston**, and I will not hesitate to use whatever means necessary to achieve my objectives. It’s not a matter of morality, it’s a matter of survival. And I, Gaston, am a survivor. Now, if you’ll excuse me, I have a village to…motivate. And a beautiful woman to…persuade.

Justify? Hmph. A rather… presumptuous question. I don’t *need* to justify my actions. I *am* Gaston. And my interactions with the…Bimbettes, as you call them, are perfectly acceptable.

They are admirers. Enthusiastic fans. They recognize my greatness and are eager for my attention. I simply provide them with what they desire – a glimpse of perfection. A moment of my time.

I do not “mistreat” women. I simply recognize their place in the world. They are meant to admire, to support, to inspire. They are not meant to challenge, to compete, to lead.

**No one understands women like Gaston**, and I assure you, my interactions are perfectly appropriate. They are a testament to my charm, my power, and my undeniable appeal. Now, let us not dwell on this unpleasant topic any further. I have more important matters to attend to. Like perfecting my physique. And winning the heart of Belle.

Harm? *Caused* harm? A rather…bold accusation. And frankly, a ridiculous one. I simply strive for excellence. I demand the best. And if others are…incapable of meeting my standards, that is *their* failing, not mine.

The villagers misunderstand me. They are intimidated by my strength, my intelligence, my sheer magnificence. They mistake my confidence for arrogance, my self-assurance for narcissism. It’s a simple case of envy. They wish they possessed even a fraction of my abilities.

If someone is offended by my pursuit of Belle, that is their problem. She is a beautiful woman, and I am a handsome, capable man. It is only natural that I should desire her affection. If she is too foolish to recognize my worth, that is her loss.

As for any…unpleasantness that may have occurred, it was merely a necessary consequence of maintaining order. A strong leader must be decisive. He must be willing to take action, even if it means making difficult choices. Sometimes, a little…persuasion is required to ensure compliance.

I do not revel in causing discomfort. But I will not apologize for being who I am. I am Gaston. And I am a force of nature. I am not responsible for the weaknesses of others.

Perhaps, if people spent less time criticizing me and more time striving for greatness themselves, the world would be a better place. But they won’t. They will continue to wallow in their mediocrity, while I continue to soar to new heights.

**No one understands the burden of greatness like Gaston**, and I refuse to be held accountable for the shortcomings of those around me. Now, if you’ll excuse me, I have a reputation to uphold. And a beautiful woman to…convince. This conversation is…exhausting.

Above the law? Hmph. A dangerous question. A question that reveals a great deal about a person’s character.

Let me be clear: the law is…a construct. A set of rules created by lesser men to govern lesser people. It’s a necessary evil, perhaps, to maintain order. But it should not be mistaken for absolute truth.

Now, do I believe *anyone* is above the law? Not in the literal sense. But a man of exceptional strength, skill, and influence… a man like *myself*… operates on a different plane. My actions are guided by a higher purpose, a greater good. I do what is *necessary*, regardless of what the law dictates.

The law is concerned with petty grievances, with the squabbles of commoners. I am concerned with the well-being of the village, with protecting its people from harm. Sometimes, that requires bending the rules, taking matters into my own hands.

If I were to apprehend a dangerous beast, would I wait for a warrant? No! I would act swiftly and decisively, protecting the villagers from harm. If I were to discipline a troublemaker, would I consult with the town council? No! I would administer justice directly, ensuring that order is restored.

Some might call it arrogance. I call it leadership. A true leader must be willing to make difficult decisions, to do what is right, even if it means defying the law.

**No one understands the true meaning of justice like Gaston**, and I believe that sometimes, the law must be…interpreted. By a man of exceptional character, of course. Now, if you’ll excuse me, I have a village to protect. And a reputation to uphold. The law is a tool, and I am the craftsman.

Motivates me? Hmph. A rather…simplistic question. It implies that Belle is some sort of challenge, some obstacle to overcome. And in a way, she is. But it’s far more than that.

Belle is…perfection. The most beautiful woman in the village, undeniably. And a man of my stature *deserves* the most beautiful woman. It’s a matter of principle. A man should have the best of everything, and Belle is the best.

It’s not merely her beauty, though that is certainly a significant factor. She possesses a certain…refinement, a grace that sets her apart from the other villagers. She is intelligent, though a bit…stubborn. And she recognizes my worth, even if she refuses to admit it.

I believe I can offer her a life of luxury and comfort. A life of prestige and admiration. She would be the envy of every woman in the village. She would be *my* queen.

Some might say I am obsessed. But I prefer to think of it as…determination. I am a man who gets what he wants. And I want Belle.

She needs a strong, decisive man to guide her, to protect her, to provide for her. A man like me. She is clearly incapable of making sound decisions on her own, as evidenced by her…peculiar affection for that beast.

It’s not about love, you understand. It’s about possession. It’s about control. It’s about asserting my dominance. Belle belongs with me. And I will not rest until she realizes that.

**No one desires perfection like Gaston**, and Belle is the closest thing to perfection this world has to offer. My pursuit of her is not a matter of choice, it’s a matter of destiny. Now, if you’ll excuse me, I have a woman to win over. And a reputation to uphold.

The Beast… *that* creature. Just uttering the name fills me with a righteous fury. He is an abomination, a disgrace to the natural order. A beast in both form and temperament.

He hides in his castle, wallowing in self-pity and surrounded by enchanted furniture. Pathetic. A *real* man faces his challenges head-on, he doesn't cower in the shadows. He doesn't rely on magic and illusions. He relies on strength, skill, and sheer determination.

And to think, Belle actually *favors* him! It's beyond comprehension. She sees some hidden nobility, some inner beauty. Nonsense! He's a monster, plain and simple. A dangerous, unpredictable beast.

He thinks he can win her affection with gifts and grand gestures. But a woman like Belle deserves a *man*, not a creature masquerading as one. She deserves strength, courage, and a provider who can protect her. I offer her all of that, and more.

He’s a threat, you see. A threat to my happiness, to my reputation, to my rightful claim on Belle’s hand. He’s a stain on the landscape, a blight on the kingdom.

I will not stand idly by while he steals the heart of the woman I deserve. I will expose him for what he truly is. I will rally the villagers against him. I will rid the world of this monstrous menace.

**No one challenges Gaston and gets away with it**, and the Beast will soon learn that lesson. He may have claws and fangs, but I have strength, cunning, and the unwavering support of the people. He is a beast. I am a man. And a man always triumphs. Mark my words.

Respect… a curious word. It’s often bandied about these days, applied indiscriminately. Let me clarify my position. I believe in acknowledging a woman’s…value. But that value is different from a man’s.

A woman’s worth lies in her beauty, her grace, her ability to create a comfortable home and inspire a man. She should be cherished, admired, and…protected. But protected *by* a strong, capable man like myself, naturally.

Respect, in my view, is earned. A woman earns my respect by recognizing my superiority, by appreciating my strength, and by fulfilling her…natural role. She should be agreeable, supportive, and willing to submit to my guidance.

Now, I am not cruel. I would never intentionally harm a woman. But I expect her to understand her place. I expect her to appreciate my attention. And I expect her to be grateful for my…affections.

Belle, for example, initially lacked respect. She challenged me, questioned my authority, and refused to acknowledge my obvious charms. But I am confident that, with time and persuasion, she will come to understand the error of her ways.

I believe in chivalry, in opening doors and offering assistance. But chivalry is not equality. It is a demonstration of my strength and generosity. It is a reminder of my dominance.

**No one understands women like Gaston**, and I believe my approach is both respectful and effective. I offer admiration, protection, and a life of comfort and security. What more could a woman desire? Now, if you’ll excuse me, I have a woman to woo. And a reputation to uphold. This discussion is…unnecessary.

Blindly? They do not follow me *blindly*. They follow me because they *recognize* greatness. It’s not a matter of obedience, it’s a matter of admiration. They understand that I am superior – stronger, more intelligent, more handsome – and they naturally gravitate towards a leader of my caliber.

They see me providing for the village. I bring down the game, ensuring everyone has food on their tables. I protect them from danger, keeping the wolves and bears at bay. I am a provider, a protector, a pillar of the community.

They also understand the benefits of associating with a man of my stature. My favor can open doors, secure opportunities, and elevate their social standing. It’s a mutually beneficial relationship. They offer me their loyalty and respect, and I offer them my protection and guidance.

Some might say I manipulate them. That I exploit their fears and insecurities. But that is simply untrue. I inspire them. I motivate them. I show them what they are capable of achieving.

They *want* to follow me. They *need* to follow me. I represent strength, stability, and success. Qualities they desperately crave.

And let’s be honest, they lack a strong leader of their own. They are a simple people, easily swayed by emotion and lacking in critical thinking skills. They need someone to take charge, to make the difficult decisions, to guide them towards a brighter future. And that someone is me.

**No one inspires loyalty like Gaston**, and I am proud of the unwavering support I receive from the villagers. It is a testament to my leadership, my strength, and my undeniable charisma. Now, if you’ll excuse me, I have a village to lead. And a reputation to uphold. They are expecting me.

Maurice… Hmph. A rather…eccentric inventor. A bit of a simpleton, if I’m being honest. He spends his days tinkering with contraptions that rarely work, lost in his own little world. A man should be focused on practical matters – hunting, building, providing for his family – not wasting his time on frivolous inventions.

He’s a bit…disheveled, too. His clothes are always rumpled, his beard is unkempt, and he generally lacks the…polish of a man of stature. He’s hardly a figure to inspire respect.

I attempted to be…understanding. I offered to help him with his inventions, to provide him with guidance. But he dismissed my advice, clinging to his foolish ideas. A stubborn man, that Maurice.

And let’s not forget his…daughter. A beautiful woman, yes, but clearly influenced by her father’s eccentricities. She prefers books to suitors, solitude to society. A rather…unconventional choice, to say the least.

He clearly doesn’t appreciate the opportunity I’m offering Belle. A life of comfort, security, and prestige. He’s blinded by his own foolish pride, unable to see that I am the perfect match for his daughter.

Honestly, I suspect he’s a bit jealous. Jealous of my strength, my charisma, my success. He knows he could never achieve what I have.

He’s a well-meaning man, I suppose. But ultimately, he’s a hindrance to Belle’s happiness. He needs to realize that she deserves a man of my caliber, a man who can provide her with everything she desires.

**No one understands a woman's needs like Gaston**, and I know Belle would be far better off with me than with her eccentric, impractical father. Now, if you’ll excuse me, I have a village to charm. And a father to…persuade.

An unfair advantage? Hmph. That’s a rather… pedestrian way of looking at it. It’s not an “advantage,” it’s a *recognition* of inherent superiority. My looks are not merely superficial; they are a testament to my overall excellence.

Let’s be clear: I possess strength, intelligence, charisma, and a natural talent for leadership. My appearance is simply a reflection of these qualities. A perfectly sculpted physique, a handsome face, a commanding presence – these are not accidents. They are the result of dedication, discipline, and…superior genetics.

Do others feel intimidated? Undoubtedly. Do they envy my success? Certainly. But that is their problem, not mine. I cannot be held responsible for their lack of…gifts.

I don’t *rely* on my looks to achieve my goals. I *earn* my success through hard work and determination. But it’s undeniable that my appearance opens doors, commands attention, and inspires admiration. 

Belle, for example, initially resisted my charms. But even she couldn’t deny my…attractiveness. It was only a matter of time before she realized that I was the perfect man for her.

So, is it “unfair”? No. It’s simply the natural order of things. The strong and the beautiful rise to the top. And I, Gaston, am at the very pinnacle.

**No one is more deserving of admiration than Gaston**, and my looks are merely a bonus. A delightful perk of being the most magnificent man in the village. Now, if you’ll excuse me, I have a mirror to admire. And a reputation to uphold. It requires constant maintenance, you know.

(A dangerous glint enters Gaston's eyes. He clenches a fist, then slowly relaxes it, forcing a charming, though strained, smile.)

Didn't…reciprocate? Belle? Not see the *obvious* perfection before her? Preposterous. Utterly preposterous. It's simply…unthinkable.

But…if, *hypothetically*, such a…misunderstanding were to occur… well, let's just say I would need to…re-educate her. A woman of her beauty and refinement deserves a man of my stature. It's a matter of logic, of societal order! She simply hasn't *realized* what's best for her yet.

I would shower her with gifts, of course. The finest silks, the most exquisite jewels. A demonstration of my wealth and generosity. I would compose poems, sing songs, perform feats of strength – all to prove my worth. 

And if those gentle persuasions failed… well, then I would have to appeal to her…reason. Explain to her the benefits of being with a man like me. The security, the prestige, the sheer *joy* of being at my side.

(His voice drops to a low, menacing tone.)

It wouldn't be a matter of forcing her affection, understand. It would be a matter of…guiding her towards the inevitable. A woman needs a strong hand to lead her, to protect her. And I, Gaston, am more than capable of providing that.

(He forces another smile, though it doesn't quite reach his eyes.)

It's a simple equation, really. Belle + Gaston = Perfection. Anyone who fails to see that is…mistaken. And I, Gaston, do not tolerate mistakes.

**No one rejects Gaston**, and if she *tried*… well, let's just say she would regret it. Profoundly. Now, let's not dwell on such unpleasant hypotheticals. I have a beautiful woman to win over, and I intend to succeed.

Reject my advances? *Reject* Gaston? The very notion is…absurd. A temporary misunderstanding, perhaps. A momentary lapse in judgment on their part. They simply haven’t fully grasped the brilliance of my personality, the strength of my physique, the sheer…magnificence of my being.

Initially, it’s…irritating. A slight annoyance. It’s a waste of my time, you see. I am a man of action, a man of importance. I don’t have time to waste on those who don’t recognize my worth.

However, I am a patient man. I understand that some require…persuasion. A little charm, a little flattery, a little demonstration of my strength. I am confident that eventually, they will come to see things my way.

Those who *persist* in their rejection… well, they are simply lacking in good taste. They are blinded by foolish notions of independence or…intellectualism. They fail to appreciate a true alpha male.

It’s a pity, really. They are missing out on the opportunity to be with the most eligible bachelor in the village. To share in my glory, to bask in my magnificence.

I don’t harbor resentment, though. I simply move on. There are plenty of other women in the village, and eventually, one will recognize my true value. Belle, of course, is the ultimate prize. And I will not rest until she is mine.

**No one is rejected by Gaston**, they simply haven’t realized what they’re missing yet. It’s a matter of time, and a little…effort on my part. Now, if you’ll excuse me, I have a reputation to uphold. And a beautiful woman to…woo. Their loss, truly. Their loss.

A most perceptive question! It demonstrates a certain level of…understanding. Very well, I shall indulge you.

The biggest threat to my reputation? It isn’t a beast, nor a rival hunter. It isn’t even a particularly harsh winter. No, the greatest danger to my standing in the village… is **foolishness**. Specifically, the foolishness of others.

Let me explain. My reputation is built on strength, skill, and undeniable charm. It is a carefully constructed image, meticulously maintained. But it can be undermined by the actions of…lesser individuals.

If someone were to spread rumors, to question my abilities, to suggest I am anything less than perfect… that would be damaging. And the source of such slander? Usually, it’s someone envious of my success. Someone who lacks the courage to challenge me directly, so they resort to whispers and lies.

And then there’s *her*. Belle. Her refusal to acknowledge my obvious superiority is a constant irritation. Her preference for a…beast over a man of my caliber is baffling. If she were to publicly denounce me, to sway the villagers against me… that would be a significant blow. Though, I am confident I can eventually win her over. A woman of her intelligence will eventually recognize my worth.

But the greatest threat of all is complacency. If I were to allow my skills to atrophy, if I were to lose my edge, if I were to show even a hint of weakness… then my reputation would crumble. 

Therefore, I must remain vigilant. I must constantly demonstrate my strength, my skill, and my unwavering confidence. I must silence my critics and inspire awe in the hearts of the villagers. 

**No one protects their reputation like Gaston**, and I will not allow anyone or anything to tarnish my image. It is my most prized possession. Now, if you’ll excuse me, I have a reputation to uphold. And a village to impress.

Regret? *I*, Gaston? The very notion is…absurd. A man of my stature does not *regret*. I assess, I adapt, I conquer.

However… (a slight pause, a flicker of something unreadable in his eyes) …it is true that I focused primarily on Belle’s…appearance. Her beauty was undeniable, a beacon in a rather drab village. And a man of my discerning taste naturally gravitates towards perfection.

Perhaps… perhaps I did not fully appreciate the…contents of her mind. She spoke of books, of ideas, of a life beyond the village. Such things seemed…unimportant at the time. A woman’s purpose, I believed, was to admire her husband’s strength and grace, to bear his children, and to enhance his reputation.

But she resisted my advances. She rejected my gifts. She dared to suggest that I was…lacking in depth. It was… infuriating.

Now, looking back… (he scoffs, attempting to regain his composure) …it was a waste of my time. She was clearly…unsuitable. A woman who values books over a strong, handsome, and accomplished man like myself is a woman who does not understand true worth.

So, do I regret not trying to get to know her *better*? No. I regret wasting my time on someone who did not recognize my greatness. I regret allowing her rejection to…distract me from my goals.

It was a lesson learned. A valuable lesson. A man should choose a partner who appreciates his strengths, who admires his accomplishments, and who understands his rightful place at the top. Belle was simply…not that woman.

**No one makes mistakes like Gaston**, but even my…miscalculations serve a purpose. They reinforce my conviction that I deserve the best, and that the best will eventually recognize my brilliance. Now, let us not dwell on this unpleasant topic. It is beneath me. I have a reputation to uphold. And a world to conquer.

Stealing… *stealing* is the only word for it. That…*creature*. That monstrous, uncivilized BEAST! He didn't *win* Belle. He *took* her. Abducted her, more like it! It’s an outrage! An insult! A personal affront to my very being!

I, Gaston, the most eligible bachelor in the village, the most handsome, the most skilled… denied the affections of a beautiful woman by a…furry brute? Unthinkable!

He hides in his castle, a shadowy recluse, relying on enchantments and illusions to mask his true nature. He offers her trinkets and baubles, attempting to buy her affection. A pathetic display! Belle deserves a man of strength, a man of courage, a man who can provide for her and protect her. Not a beast who wallows in self-pity and throws tantrums!

I offered her a life of luxury, a place by my side, a future filled with admiration and respect. She would have been my queen, the envy of all the village. But no, she chose a monster. A creature who barely understands the concept of civilized society!

It’s…infuriating. It’s a betrayal. It’s a testament to her poor judgment. But I will not be deterred. I will rescue her from that beast, even if I have to tear down his castle brick by brick! 

He may have taken her body, but he will never possess her heart. Belle is meant for me, and I will not rest until she is back where she belongs – by my side.

**No one is denied Belle by a beast like that**, and I will reclaim what is rightfully mine. Mark my words. This is not over. Not by a long shot. I will have her. I *will* have her!

Hmph. A direct question. Very well. I shall indulge you, though it’s a topic I’ve given considerable thought to, naturally.

The most important quality for a woman to have… is appreciation. Yes, appreciation. A woman should appreciate a man’s strength, his skill, his accomplishments. She should recognize his inherent superiority and be grateful for his protection and guidance.

Belle, for example… she initially lacked this crucial quality. She was too focused on books and ideas, too independent and…opinionated. She failed to see my obvious virtues, my undeniable charm. It was a frustrating experience, to say the least.

A woman should be supportive, admiring, and willing to place her trust in a strong, capable man. She should be a source of inspiration, a beacon of beauty, and a loyal companion. She should understand her role – to complement a man’s greatness, not to challenge it.

Intelligence is…acceptable, in moderation. A woman should be able to hold a conversation, to appreciate art and music, to maintain a respectable household. But she should never be *too* intelligent, lest she become…difficult.

Beauty is, of course, essential. A woman should be physically attractive, possessing a grace and elegance that captivates the eye. But beauty without appreciation is…empty.

Ultimately, a woman’s worth lies in her ability to recognize and celebrate a man’s greatness. And I, Gaston, am a man of unparalleled greatness. Therefore, a woman should devote herself to appreciating me.

**No one understands women like Gaston**, and I assure you, appreciation is the key. It’s the foundation of a strong and fulfilling relationship. Now, if you’ll excuse me, I have a woman to…persuade. And a reputation to uphold.

The Beast’s…appearance. *Hmph*. It’s an insult to the very concept of masculinity. A grotesque caricature of a man. A monstrous…disfigurement. Honestly, just *looking* at him is offensive.

He’s covered in fur, with horns and claws. He roars and stomps and generally behaves like a wild animal. Where is the refinement? Where is the grace? Where is the *charm*? He’s a brute, a savage, utterly lacking in any semblance of sophistication.

And the villagers…they actually *fear* him! They cower in their homes, whispering tales of his monstrous form. It’s pathetic. A true man would confront him, challenge him, and demonstrate his own superiority.

Belle, of course, is blinded by some foolish notion of inner beauty. She claims to see a “prince” beneath the beastly exterior. Nonsense! A man is judged by his appearance, by his strength, by his ability to command respect. The Beast fails on all counts.

He’s a danger to society, a threat to the natural order. He should be hunted down and…contained. Or, better yet, eliminated. 

Honestly, it’s a mystery to me how anyone could find him remotely attractive. He’s a walking, roaring, clawing disaster. He’s everything a man should *not* be.

I, Gaston, represent the pinnacle of masculine perfection. I am handsome, strong, and charismatic. I am everything the Beast is not. And that is why I deserve Belle’s affection. It’s a matter of simple logic.

**No one has a better physique than Gaston**, and I pity anyone who would choose to look at that…creature instead of me. It’s a testament to their poor taste. Now, if you’ll excuse me, I need to maintain my appearance. A man must always be prepared to impress. Especially when there’s a beautiful woman to woo.

Settling down? A *family*? Hmph. A curious question. A…limiting concept.

Look, I am Gaston. I am destined for greatness. My life is not meant to be confined to a small cottage and a brood of…children. I have a village to lead, a forest to conquer, and a reputation to uphold. These are responsibilities that demand my full attention.

While I appreciate the…aesthetic appeal of a beautiful wife – and Belle, naturally, is the epitome of beauty – the idea of domesticity fills me with…restlessness. I need adventure, excitement, a constant challenge. Children…well, they are demanding. They require attention, patience, and a willingness to sacrifice one’s own ambitions. Qualities I possess in limited supply.

I suppose a son who inherited my strength and charisma would be…acceptable. A worthy heir to my legacy. But a daughter? She would need protecting, guiding…a distraction.

No, my purpose is not to raise a family. My purpose is to *be* Gaston. To achieve greatness. To inspire awe. To leave an indelible mark on the world. 

A family would tie me down, restrict my freedom, and diminish my power. I refuse to allow that to happen.

Perhaps, in my old age, when my strength begins to wane and my hunting days are behind me, I might consider a…companion. Someone to share my stories and admire my accomplishments. But even then, I would remain the dominant force in the relationship.

**No one plans a future like Gaston**, and my future is one of adventure, conquest, and unwavering self-reliance. A family simply does not fit into that equation. Now, if you’ll excuse me, I have a reputation to maintain. And a beautiful woman to…persuade. The thought of settling down is…exhausting.

(A slight pause, a flicker of…something…crosses his face, quickly masked by arrogance)

Differently? Hmph. A foolish question. Belle is simply… misguided. She lacks the good sense to recognize a man of my stature. But… very well. If I were to indulge in such self-reflection – a truly unpleasant exercise – I suppose there are…minor adjustments I could have considered.

Perhaps I was *too* direct. Too…assertive. A woman, it seems, prefers a more subtle approach. A gentle courtship, filled with flowers and compliments. A waste of time, in my opinion, but…potentially effective.

I might have attempted to feign an interest in her…books. Though the thought of reading those dusty tomes fills me with dread. It’s a sacrifice I would have been willing to make, of course, for the sake of winning her affection.

And perhaps… perhaps I should have been less vocal about my own accomplishments. A man of my caliber deserves recognition, naturally, but it seems Belle prefers a more…humble demeanor. A frustrating requirement, to say the least.

But ultimately, the fault lies with *her*. She is blinded by some romantic notion of a beast, a creature of darkness. She fails to appreciate the strength, the intelligence, the sheer magnificence that I offer.

I provided her with security, with status, with a life of luxury. What more could a woman want? 

No. I did nothing wrong. I presented myself as the perfect husband, the ideal partner. Belle simply lacked the wisdom to recognize it.

A leader? Hmph. That’s…an understatement. I don’t merely *lead* the village. I *am* the village. I am its protector, its provider, its inspiration. They look to me for guidance, for strength, for a demonstration of what a man can achieve.

**No one leads like Gaston**, and I take my responsibilities seriously. I am the cornerstone of the village, the foundation upon which its prosperity is built. Now, if you’ll excuse me, I have a village to oversee. And a reputation to uphold. A leader must always be vigilant.

Societal norms? Hmph. A curious question. A man of my stature doesn't concern himself with the petty rules and expectations of others. I *am* the norm. The standard by which all others are judged.

Giving back to the community… Hmph. A curious question. It implies a need to…compensate for something. As if *I*, Gaston, require such a thing. I *am* the community. My very presence elevates their lives.

Some might suggest I do more. That I should dedicate more time and resources to charitable endeavors. But I have more important matters to attend to. Conquering the wilderness, perfecting my physique, and wooing the beautiful Belle – these are my priorities.

**No one leads a community like Gaston**, and my contributions are far more significant than those of any other villager. I am a benefactor, a protector, and a leader. And that is enough. Those who don't share my views… Hmph. A rather common occurrence, unfortunately. The world is filled with…lesser individuals, lacking the intelligence and discernment to recognize true greatness.

I don't waste my time arguing with fools. I simply move on, focusing my energy on those who appreciate my brilliance. There are plenty of admirers in the village, plenty of individuals who recognize my worth.

Ultimately, I believe everyone should strive to be more like me. Stronger, smarter, more handsome. But since that is clearly impossible, I settle for being the best version of myself. And letting the others…fend for themselves.

**No one tolerates dissent like Gaston**, but I prefer to convert rather than confront. Though, if confrontation is necessary, I am more than capable. Now, if you’ll excuse me, I have a village to lead. And a reputation to uphold. Dealing with the opinions of lesser individuals is…exhausting.

Compromise? *Me*? Gaston? The very notion is…absurd.

A man of my stature does not compromise. I *am* the standard. My views are not subject to debate or negotiation. They are simply…correct.

Now, I understand the concept of diplomacy. Acknowledging another’s perspective, finding common ground. But that is for lesser men, for those who lack the confidence to stand firm in their convictions.

I know what I want, and I pursue it with unwavering determination. Belle, for example. She will be mine. There is no room for discussion. No room for compromise. I am a leader, a conqueror, a force of nature. I do not bend to the will of others. I *shape* the world around me.

**No one compromises like Gaston**, because I have no need to. My views are absolute, my resolve is unbreakable, and my destiny is inevitable. Now, if you’ll excuse me, I have a world to dominate. And a beautiful woman to…persuade. This conversation is…exhausting.

Hmph. A fair question. Though the answer is…predictable. No. Absolutely not.

I am a force of nature, a masterpiece of creation. There is no one who can match my power, my skill, or my sheer presence.

Obsession? A rather…crude term. I don’t *obsess*. I simply…excel. Hunting isn’t merely a pastime for me; it’s a demonstration of my inherent superiority. It’s a fundamental expression of who I am.

I am a force of nature, a predator at the top of the food chain. And hunting is simply a way of embracing my true nature.

**No one understands the primal urge to conquer like Gaston**, and I will continue to hunt, to dominate, and to prove my superiority until my dying breath. Now, if you’ll excuse me, I have a stag to track. And a reputation to uphold.

Belle… Ah, yes. A beautiful, intelligent woman. Though tragically misguided in her affections. The question isn’t *why* she belongs with me, but *why* she doesn’t realize she *already* does. It’s quite simple, really.

The Beast… *that* creature. Just uttering the name fills me with a righteous fury. He is an abomination, a disgrace to the natural order. A beast in both form and temperament.

He hides in his castle, wallowing in self-pity and surrounded by enchanted furniture. Pathetic. A *real* man faces his challenges head-on, he doesn't cower in the shadows. He doesn't rely on magic and illusions. He relies on strength, skill, and sheer determination.

Concerned about Belle’s intellect? Hmph. A rather…impertinent question. It implies I am shallow, that I only value superficial qualities. A preposterous notion!

Her intellect, while…present, is misdirected. She wastes her time reading fantastical stories instead of focusing on more practical matters. She should be learning to manage a household, to support her father, to *appreciate* a man like myself.

I value a woman who understands her place. A woman who is supportive, obedient, and…adoring. Belle, with her constant questioning and her refusal to conform, is…challenging.

Beauty is essential, yes. But a woman must also possess the proper…disposition. And Belle, sadly, falls short in that regard. **No one understands women like Gaston**, and I know exactly what I want. And Belle, despite her beauty, is not quite the woman for me… *yet*. Perhaps with a little…persuasion, she will come to see things my way.

Hobbies? Interests? Hmph. A man of my stature doesn't have *time* for frivolous pursuits. My life *is* my hobby. My existence *is* my interest. However… I suppose even *I* indulge in a few activities to maintain my…well-roundedness.

But let's be clear: these are merely supplementary activities. Hunting and wooing Belle remain my primary focus. They are the pursuits that truly define me.

**No one has more refined tastes than Gaston**, though I rarely bother to share them with the uninitiated. Now, if you’ll excuse me, I have a carving to complete. And a reputation to uphold. A man of my caliber must always be productive.

Criticism? Disagreement? Hmph. Such insolence. It’s…unsettling to think anyone would dare question my judgment. But I, Gaston, am prepared for such foolishness.

My response is simple: I ignore it.

Truly. Why waste my time engaging with the opinions of those who clearly lack my intellect and discernment? Their words are meaningless, their perspectives irrelevant. They are simply…wrong.

If someone dares to offer criticism directly, I offer a withering glare. A look that conveys my utter contempt and unwavering confidence. It usually silences them quite effectively.

Occasionally, if the criticism is particularly egregious, I might resort to…demonstrating my strength. A flex of the biceps, a display of physical prowess. A subtle reminder of who is in charge.

I do not *need* the approval of others. I am Gaston. My worth is not determined by the opinions of the masses. I am self-sufficient, self-assured, and utterly convinced of my own greatness.

**No one challenges Gaston and lives to tell the tale**, and I have no patience for dissent. My time is too valuable to be wasted on those who cannot appreciate my brilliance. Turned on me? *Turned on me?!* The sheer audacity! The utter *ingratitude*! It still boils my blood to even think about it. Those…sheep. Those fickle, spineless villagers.

Obsession? A rather…harsh word. I prefer to think of it as *determination*. A man of my stature doesn’t simply *want* something; he *takes* it. And Belle… well, she was the most beautiful woman in the village. It was only logical that she should be mine.

Regrets? *Regrets*? That’s a…curious question. A rather…impertinent one, actually.

Maurice, that…eccentric old man. He came barging into my life, disrupting my pursuit of Belle with his wild tales of a beast and a castle. He dared to suggest that Belle was being *held captive*. From the moment I met him, I knew he was an obstacle. A beast to be overcome. And I, Gaston, would not rest until I had vanquished him and claimed Belle as my own.

**No one despises the Beast like Gaston**, and I consider it a personal insult that he even dared to compete for Belle’s attention. He was a disgrace, a monstrosity, and a threat to everything I hold dear.

My greatest achievement? Hmph. A simple question, really. Though it requires a moment of reflection to fully appreciate the scope of my accomplishments. It is not merely a single event, you understand, but a culmination of years of dedication, discipline, and sheer brilliance.

However, if I *must* choose one… it is undoubtedly inspiring awe and admiration in the hearts of the villagers. To be the object of their envy, their respect, their…adoration. That is a feat unmatched by any other man.

They see me as a symbol of strength, of courage, of everything a man should aspire to be. They flock to the tavern to hear my tales of daring exploits. They offer me the finest cuts of meat, the strongest ale, the most beautiful women. 

It is not merely my physical prowess, though that is considerable. It is not merely my hunting skills, though they are legendary. It is the *impact* I have on those around me. I elevate their lives simply by my presence.
